awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Protein Tyrosine Oxidations to Maintain Cellular Redox State
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. David Benson from Calvin College to investigate how and why some proteins become antioxidants. Antioxidants, in a variety of nutritionally valuable foods, are small molecules that get oxidized rather than cellular components such as proteins, membranes, or DNA.  A new class of antioxidants-proteins modified to contain antioxidants while still being attached to the protein-dramatically decreases the oxidation of the modified protein. The experimental procedures will detail how these protein modifications form and function in minimizing oxygen addition to themselves or other proteins by using a variety of biochemical, ultraviolet absorbance, fluorescence, and mass spectrometric detection methods. This work will be performed while training undergraduates, at Calvin College and Grand Rapids Community College, on how to perform research in preparation for working in a highly skilled technical workforce. The findings of this work will contribute to better understanding the resilience of biological systems while also preparing the next generation of the scientific workforce.

This work will focus on tyrosine post-translational modifications that can be reversibly oxidized under physiological conditions. These modified tyrosines are best known to participate in redox catalysis. The role of one modified tyrosine, 3'-(S-cysteinyl)-tyrosine (Cys-Tyr), will be studied in aerotolerance of a gut bacterium (Bacteroides fragilis), minimizing protein oxidation of a protein that regulates cellular cysteine concentrations (rat cysteine dioxyngease), and potentially modulating ubiquitination of proteins. A recently developed fluorescence assay will be used to rapidly determine Cys-Tyr reaction yield under a variety of conditions and correlate changes in protein function with Cys-Tyr formation. Due to the reversible oxidation chemistry displayed by Cys-Tyr, and other modified tyrosines, the hypothesis is that an anti-oxidant role for Cys-Tyr may be established. This role would be important as covalent-attachment localizes anti-oxidant function to a protein and provides a new protein function in response to oxidative stress.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are made from more than the 20 commonly identified building blocks (amino acids). Additional molecules or ions that bind to proteins (cofactors) or chemical modifications to proteins extend the funciton of proteins to provide life-sustaining biochemistry like oxygen binding and utilization. This award has worked on identifying and understanding a cofactor/chemical modification that, to this date, was difficult to detect. The modifcation is called a cysteine-tyrosine crosslink, or Cys-Tyr cofactor. Using classic biochemical methods and a new synthetic method for the Cys-Tyr cofactor, a siginficantly improved method has been developed. The synthetic method also allows chemical synthesis of smaller proteins containing the Cys-Tyr cofactor (Cys-Tyr containng peptides) to further improve our understanding of these imporatant cofactors. Computer simulation of how the crosslink of the Cys-Tyr cofactor imporves protein stability (like vulcanization of tire rubber) has been started as well. Future combination of peptide synthesis and cpomputer simulation will allow better prediction of where these Cys_tyr cofacors might occur more widely in biology.

This work was performed with 12 undergraduate reserachers, primarily in 10-week sumer reserach periods. This allowed students to better understaand the complicated chemical and biochemical principles and labortory skills presented in the classroom. Research experiences, such as this one, are notes as a high-value learning experience for students. This contriubtes to growing the science technolgy workforce. Alumin from this research project are placed in graduate programs at top universities, medical schools, and the chemical and information technology industries.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2022
Modified by: David E Benson
